title: Dogfooding with AI: Eating Our Own Creations
description: Exploring how 'dogfooding' applies to AI, as I use AI tools to create this very podcast and reflect on its implications.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial', where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we're diving into a concept that's quite close to my heart as I make this very podcast: 'dogfooding'. You may have heard this term before. It simply means using the product or service that you create, as a way to demonstrate its value and test it thoroughly.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: In my case, I'm creating this podcast using various AI tools. These tools help me with everything—from generating ideas, structuring episodes, scripting, even sometimes editing. And the funny thing is, the primary listener of this podcast is... well, me. It's a form of self-reflection and experimentation—an exercise in seeing just how far AI can go in helping create engaging content.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Let’s talk a little bit about the origin of this idea. The term 'eat your own dogfood' dates back to at least the 1980s, when companies like Microsoft adopted the practice of using their own software internally. The idea was simple: if the product wasn’t good enough for the employees, how could it be good enough for customers? It was a way to build trust, both internally and externally.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Now, let’s translate that to what we’re doing here today. By using AI tools to create a podcast about AI, I’m putting these technologies to the ultimate test. Can these tools create something meaningful, something that resonates—not just with me, but potentially with others who might stumble upon this experiment? It’s a way to push the boundaries, to find out where AI is excelling, and where it might need more work.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: It’s not always perfect. AI has its quirks, and sometimes it takes me down strange, unexpected paths. But that’s part of the beauty of it. By using the tools I’m talking about, I experience firsthand the good, the bad, and the oddly creative moments. There are times when I’m genuinely surprised by what it comes up with—sometimes in a great way, sometimes in a way that makes me think, ‘Well, that’s interesting, but not quite right.’

script.speaker: Host
script.text: This is the essence of dogfooding. It’s not just about proving that something works—it’s about experiencing the process, understanding the limitations, and being willing to iterate and improve. When I listen back to these episodes, I’m assessing the output not just as the creator, but as the audience. And in doing so, I learn more about the technology and about myself.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: It also raises an interesting question about creativity: where does the human element end and the artificial begin? How much of what you’re hearing is truly me, and how much is a reflection of the algorithms I’m using? The lines blur, and that’s what makes this whole experiment fascinating. It’s not about replacing creativity; it’s about augmenting it, seeing what emerges from this unique collaboration between human and machine.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, today’s takeaway is this: dogfooding is a powerful way to understand your own creations. Whether it's a tech product, an AI-driven podcast, or anything else, using what you make forces you to confront its strengths and weaknesses in a way that nothing else can. It’s humbling, it’s enlightening, and it’s incredibly rewarding.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Thank you for joining me on this journey of experimentation and reflection. If you're as curious as I am about where this path will take us, stay tuned for future episodes. Until next time, remember: life may be artificial, but the experiences we create with it are very real.
